clinical_study.brief_title: Effect of Rose-colored Glass on Mood
clinical_study.official_title: Effect of Rose-colored Glass on Mood: A Randomized Clinical Trial

brief_summary.textblock: Decades of psychological research has highlighted the impact of visual perception on mood and happiness. The investigators hypothesized that literally seeing the world through rose colored glasses may have an effect on perception, mood, and happiness. After cataract surgery, which classically increases the vividness of perceived colors, patients report significant satisfaction. The investigators therefore sought to explore whether using pink colored lenses leads to a measurable impact on outcomes.

detailed_description.textblock:
A randomized controlled clinical trial design will be performed. Subjects will be randomized for either pink lenses (treatment group) or clear lenses (placebo group).
Subjects will be asked to wear the assigned glasses throughout the day during the course of the trial. Glasses will not be work while driving at night.

primary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Anxiety Scores on the Visual Analogue Scale at 1 week
primary_outcome.description: Scale range 0-100, higher values represent more anxiety

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Mood Scores on the Visual Analogue Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Scale range 0-100, higher values represent more sadness

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in Happiness Scores on the Visual Analogue Scale
secondary_outcome.description: Scale range 0-100, higher values represent more happiness

secondary_outcome.measure: Change from baseline in the Center for Epidemiological Studies Depression Scale score
secondary_outcome.description: Scale range 0-60, higher values suggest more depressive symptoms

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects over 18 years of age.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Subjects who wear glasses on a regular basis.
